L3.1 # of policies/laws/strategies currently being implemented to meet the needs of key populations as a result of programme contribution

description.narrative: # of by-laws for sustainable and inclusive development that are better implemented as a result of CSO engagement

comment.narrative: There has been a Theory of Change (ToC) for PWUD in South Africa since 2015. The establishment of SANPUD was part of the ToC and a team of about 10 researchers, academics and community members facilitated rights affirming harm reduction activities, networks, and services for PWUD in South Africa, including: • South Africa’s first non-abstinence based facility, the first OST demonstration project, the first networks, the first needle services program, the first municipality-funded harm reduction program in Africa, the first integrated community oriented primary care program to include people who use drugs, the first HCV treatment program and prevalence study and the first representative network and implemented the first CDC and Global Fund PWUD projects in South Africa • SANPUD has written the Global Fund and PEPFAR OST and NSS protocols, the National Department of Health OST and NSS guidelines, the SA HIV Clinicians Society Harm Reduction Guidelines, changed the entire policy direction of the National Drug Master Plan, over 40 journal articles and book chapters including some by members of the networks. • Because of SANPUD there are over 1200 fifth-year trained medical students, hundreds of police, over 500 community members, NGOs, community health workers, social workers in harm reduction, human rights and decriminalisation • SANPUD partners with UNODC, UNAIDS, National Department of Health, the National Department of Social Development, SANAC and others.
No target was set as this disaggregation was not a priority for SANPUD in 2021.
This was not a focus for SANPUD in 2021 and no work was planned for this indicator therefore there are no actual results to report in 2021.

The Deputy Minister of Social Development, Hendrietta Bogopane-Zulu, plans to replicate the Bellhaven model in other parts of the country. The roll out will be done in partnership with SANPUD, who is formally recognised as a partner of the Ministry. There will be a separate proposal for this as part of the strategic investment fund. The model requires some explanation and have attached a brief overview. SANPUD continue to advise the National Department of Health and Social Development on matters affecting people who used drugs. In 2021 SANPUD provided input, leadership and support for the joint hepatitis plan for Department of Health and Department of Social Development, led the development of OST guidelines, SANPUD led on getting Methadone and Buprenorphine onto the National Essential Drugs List. The significantly changed National Drug Master Plan is being implemented, and SANPUD is regularly holding various stakeholders accountable. The National Drug Master Plan was developed over several years with inpud from communities and stakeholders. We cannot openly discuss how we ensure the five principles were included. But it involves a lot of private meetings with key stakeholders individually.

title.narrative: Diverse KP communities are organised and meaningfully inclusive and have strengthened their capacity to claim their rights and freedoms.
Description of the link between Love Alliance indicators with MoFA basket indicators
S1.2 # of civil society organisations and community led organisations with increased capacity to advocate for the rights of key populations

description.narrative: # of CSOs (not youth or women led) with increased L&A capacities

comment.narrative: South Africa has well-developed civil society and community-led organisations, with communities of sex workers and LGBTIQ+ communities displaying world-class organizing and advocacy. Approximately 10% of the organisations are youth-led and 60% refer to women-led CSOs in the country. Despite a restrictive policy environment, sex workers are well-organised. The community of people who use drugs, while more recent in their organizing, also serves as a regional leader. For example in 2017 the national network, SANPUD, was established. SANPUD has ten members of PWUD-led groups and informal organisations. Through support of Bridging the Gaps, TB HIV Care has started-up the first South African comprehensive harm reduction programme in 2016. Currently, South Africa has four harm reduction projects aimed at HIV prevention among people who inject drugs. One funded by the Global Fund operates in four cities: Cape Town, eThekwini & Nelson Mandela Bay are run by TBHIV Care as the Step Up Project, the Johannesburg site is under the care of Anova Health. PEPFAR/CDC fund the HARMless project in Pretoria, and the University of Pretoria department of family medicine has secured funds to run a community oriented substance use programme (COSUP). Other organisations include Anova Health, TB HIV Care and Foundation for Professional Development.

South Africa has well-developed civil society and community-led organisations, with communities of sex workers and LGBTIQ+ communities displaying world-class organizing and advocacy. Approximately 10% of the organisations are youth-led and 60% refer to women-led CSOs in the country.

Training was provided to simplify the call for proposal to ensure the network eligibility for funding. A total of 54 people were invited across 14 different organisations with 20 people attending across the 14 organisations. Only 3 organisations (Bellhaven (community-led), THC (community-led and PLHIV) and STAND (community-led)) that attended the training successfully obtained funding and 1 (Siyasonke) (youth and community-led) went on to be able to apply for funding from alternative sources as they were more confident in putting in proposals. However, in total 14 organisations were strengthened from this training in their ability to apply for funding. The overall result is an increase in capacity and knowledge of the networks and organisations.
